Replies.Reply: My dear Mr Bennet, have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last?
Do you not want to know who has taken it?
What a fine thing for our girls!
My dear Mr Bennet, how can you be so tiresome! You know that he must marry one of them.
- So you must go and visit him at once.
You have?
no compassion for my poor nerves?
Is he amiable?
It is a pleasure. I have two others but  40 they are already dancing.
Oh Mr Bennet! I remember the time when I liked a red coat myself, and if a smart young colonel with six thousand a year should want one of my girls I shall not say nay to him.
help from couturiers.
It is a pity she is not more handsome.
But Lizzie will never admit she is plain.
Of course it's my Jane who's considered the beauty of the county.
When she was only fifteen there was a gentleman so much in love with her that I was sure he would make her an offer.
And then he danced the third with Miss Lucas. Poor thing, it is a shame she is not more handsome. The fourth with a Miss King of little standing. And the fifth again with Jane.
Oh, Mr Bennet! Anybody would think the girls looked forward to a grand inheritance.
As you well know, Mr Bennet, when you die, which may in fact be very soon, our girls will be left without a roof over their head nor a penny to their name.
Praise the Lord! We are saved.
Make haste, Jane, make haste. 0 happy day!
This is most unfortunate.
Certainly not my dear, you will go to Netherfield on horse back.
Excellent. Now she will have to stay the night. Exactly as I predicted.
People do not die of colds.
Nonsense, the horse is with Jane. And the girls took the carriage to town.
Walk! You will not be fit to be seen by the time you get there.
Well, my dear, its all going according to plan. He's half in love with her already!
Mr Bingley! And he doesn't mind that she hasn't a penny, for he has enough for the two of them.
What an excellent room you have sir. Such expensive furnishings. I hope you intend to stay here, Mr Bingley.
But I assure you there is quite as much going on in the country as there is in the town.
What a high and mighty man that Mr Darcy is, quite eaten up with pride.
They are.
Mr Collins, we are perfectly able to keep a cook.
Does she have any family?
Mr Collins, unfortunately it is incumbent on me to hint that the eldest Miss Bennet is - very soon to be engaged.
But Miss Elizabeth next to her in both age and beauty would make anyone an excellent partner. Do not you agree, Mr Collins?
I dare say I have never met a more pleasant gentleman in all my years. Look how he dotes on her! Still Jane has always done what is best for her family.
I have never had such a good time in my life. Mr Bingley you must have such a ball once a month at least.
Don't be impertinent. our hosts are perfectly happy with our company, are you not, Mr Bingley? I hope I can entice you to Longbourn to sample our hospitality.
So tell me Mr Bingley. Whom did you like least of all your guests this evening?
Allowing for new carriages, dresses etcetera, etcetera. We will be having a wedding here at Netherfield in less than three months, if you ask me. Mr Bennet?
Oh! Yes. Certainly - Lizzy would be very happy indeed. Please -- go ahead. No time like the present. Everyone. Out. Mr Collins would like a private audience with your sister.
No. Nonsense, Lizzy. I desire you-will stay where you are. Everyone else, to the drawing room. Mr Bennet.
Now!
sshhh.
- we shall have this little hiccup dealt with immediately, Mr Collins.
Oh Mr Bennet. We are all in a uproar. You must come and make Lizzy marry Mr Collins, for she vows she will not have him.
Mr Collins, Mr Collins has proposed to Lizzie. But Lizzy declares she will not have him, and now the danger is Mr Collins may not have Lizzy.
Speak to Lizzy.
Tell her that you insist upon them marrying.
You will have this house!
You'll save your sisters from destitution!
Go back now and say you've changed your mind!
Think of your family!
Mr Bennet, say something!
Yes, or I shall never see her again?
- who will maintain you when your father is dead?
Give my love to my sister. And try not to be so much of a burden, dear.
Oh, if I could but go to Brighton -
I'm sure I cried for two days when Colonel Millar's regiment went away.
Why did the Foresters let her out of their sight? I always said they were unfit to have charge of her.
- and The Collins' will turn us out before he is cold in his grave -
We are ruined. Ruined.
Lydia married! And at sixteen too! Ring the bell, Kitty! I must put on my things and tell Lady Lucas! Oh to see her face!
And so he should help! He's much richer than us, and he hasn't got any children.
A daughter, married!
Now where will they live? Purvis Lodge might do. Ashworth is vacant of course, but it's too far off, I couldn't bear to have her ten miles from me -
Write to me often, my dear'.
Oh there is nothing so bad as parting with ones children! One seems so forlorn without them.
Mr Bingley?
Tomorrow?
Not that I care about it. Mr Bingley is nothing to us and I'm sure I never want to see him again.
No, we shall not mention a word about it.
Is it quite certain he is coming?
Huh! Come along, girls.
Oh my goodness! Everybody act naturally.
Whatever you do, do not appear overbearing.
Mr Darcy indeed! The very insolence of 0 0 it. What does he think of coming here?
Stop that and sit down! Find yourself some work! Oh Lord.

How very glad we are to see you, Mr Bingley! There are a great many changes since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled. And one of my own daughters too, you will have seen it in the papers though it was not put in as it ought to have been. Very short, nothing about her family.
- but it's very hard to have my Lydia taken away from me. Mr Wickham has been transferred to Newcastle, where ever that is. Thank heaven he has some friends.
When you have killed all your own birds, Mr Bingley, I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please.
My Jane looks well, does she not?
You must come again. For when you were in town last winter you promised to take a family dinner with us. I have not forgot you see. At least three courses.
Girls. Everybody to the kitchen.
Thank the Lord for that. I thought it would never happen.
Exceed their income? He has five thousand a year! I knew she could not be so beautiful for nothing.
All but one, the youngest has been lately married your ladyship. And my eldest was only proposed to yesterday afternoon.
Rosings, but it is larger than Sir William Lucas's, I can assure you.
Lizzie!
Lizzie, where have you been. We thought something had happened to you.
Mr Darcy! What on earth are you doing here?
Bow can it affect them?
Oh, so that is his design in settling here?
There is no need, for I already have.
You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for them; they are my constant companions these twenty years.
I will give my hearty consent to his marrying whichever of the girls he chooses.
I believe so.
And what do you say, Mary? Are you not excited by the prospect of a ball?
I have long suspected that we have two of the silliest girls in the county.
would have sprained his ankle in the first dance.
Kitty, be so kind as to pass the butter.
Good grief, woman. Your skills in the art of match-making are without question.
Well, my dear, if your daughter does die it will be a comfort to know it was all in pursuit of Mr Bingley.
Why the devil not. We could have them all laid up at Netherfield Hall.

party.

How happy for you, Mr Collins, to possess the talent for flattering with delicacy.
Mary dear, you've delighted us long enough.
Let the other young ladies have a turn.
And what am I to do?
So, your mother insists on you marrying Mr Collins.-
Well, Lizzie. From this day on you must be a stranger to one of your parents -
Your mother will never see you again if you do not marry Mr Collins, and I will never see you again if you do.
Poor Jane. However, a girl likes to be crossed in love now and then. It gives her something to think of, and a sort of distinction among her companions.
It's your turn now, Lizzie. Since you've turned down Mr Collins you're free to go off and be jilted yourself. What about Mr Wickham? He is a pleasant fellow and would do the job credibly.
Lydia will never be easy till she has exposed herself in some public place or other, and we can never expect her to do it with so little inconvenience as under the present circumstances.
Colonel Forster is a sensible man and will keep her out of any real mischief, and she is far too poor to be an object of prey to anyone.

I'm sure the officers will find women better worth their while. Let us hope, in fact, that her stay in Brighton will teach her her own insignificance. At any rate she can hardly grow any worse, without authorizing us to lock her up for the rest of her life.
Well, at least the house will be quieter.
Excuse me.
For God's sake let me be!
Lizzie, help me with my boots.
Where else could they be so well concealed?
No Lizzie. Let me once in my life feel how much I have been to blame.
I am not afraid of being overpowered by the experience. It will pass away soon enough.
He's found them.
Just wait. I can't make out his script.
Of course I will agree. But how much your uncle has laid on this wretched man already is anybody's guess.
No man in his senses would marry Lydia on so slight a temptation as a hundred a year.
Your uncle is very generous.
Wickham's a fool if he takes her for less than ten thousand pounds. I should be sorry to think so ill of him in the very -
Before you take any of these houses, Mrs Bennet, let us be clear. Into one house she will never be welcome.
That is out. of the question.
their tempers are much alike. They will be cheated assiduously by their servants, and be so generous with the rest, they will always exceed their income.
Could I offer you a cup of tea, perhaps?
Lizzie, what on earth is going on?
Lizzie, are you out of your senses? I thought you hated the man.
He is rich, to be sure, and you will have more fine carriages than Jane. But will that make you happy?
None at all. We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of fellow, but this would be nothing if you really liked him.
What has he done?
Good Lord. I must pay him back.
You do love him, don't you?
I cannot believe that anyone can deserve you, but it seems I am over-ruled. So I heartily give my consent.
I could not have parted with you, my Lizzie, to any one less worthy.
Have you heard? A Mr Bingley, a young man from the North of England, has come down on Monday in a chaise and four.
- and he's single to be sure!
Oh, yes, Papa.
He's sure to be handsome.
So will he come to the ball tomorrow?
I need it!
I literally can't breathe its so tight.
Mama! The regiment is arriving next week!
They're going to be stationed in the village!
officers! Lots of officers!

sir' and blush prettily and then you're introduced!

I can't believe it, there must be a thousand of them.

And we met Mr Wickham.

Oh yes!

She is!

Mrs Forster has invited me.
- because she likes me better.

- and then we passed Sarah Sims in her carriage so I took off my glove and let my hand just rest on the window frame, so she might see the ring, and then 1 bowed and smiled like anything!
Jane, I take your place now, and you must go lower, for I am the married woman.
You must all go to Brighton, for that is the place to get husbands! I hope you have half my good luck.
Well, Monday morning came and I was in such a fuss -
- there was my aunt, preaching and talking away just as if she was reading a sermon, she was horrid unpleasant -
- and then my uncle was called away from the church on business and I thought -
I forgot! I shouldn't have said a word!
He was the one that discovered us! He knew where to find Wickham, you see.
But don't tell anyone! He told me not to tell!
Come on, Wickham! You've got to play.
I'm not supposed to tell.
Because he paid for it.
The wedding, Wickham's commission.
People kept saying Wickham owed them money, it was so tedious. So Darcy settled his debts but I don't really like him, do you?
favorite.

- if you do, I'll lend you my green slippers.

- who is to fight Wickham and make him marry Lydia, now you've come home?

Why did you not tell me. Did he mention Mr Bingley.

end the evening completely in love with you then I am no judge of beauty.

in driving away love?

Oh dancing, of course. Even if ones partner is barely tolerable.
Handsome, conveniently rich -
I agree entirely, only the deepest love will persuade me into matrimony, which is why I will end up an old maid.
Jane, he danced with you most of the night.
That is one great difference between us.
You're a great deal too apt to like people in general, you know. All the world is good and agreeable in your eyes.

I'm so sorry. How is my sister?

i am no longer surprised at your knowing only six accomplished women. I rather wonder now at your knowing any.
certainly be a fearsome thing to behold.

will not be affected by your difficult relations with the gentleman we were just speaking of.

No, not at all.

We never had a governess.

Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. But I think it would be very hard on younger sisters, not to have their share of amusement because the elder is still unmarried. And to be kept back on such a motive! It would hardly encourage sisterly affection.
No, I beg you -
Please, I told you I play poorly -

Mr Darcy!

I'm afraid Mr and Mrs Collins are gone on business to the village.
He is indeed lucky to have found one of the few sensible women who would have accepted him.
Shall I call for some tea?

I do imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly to have someone to order around. I wonder he does not marry and secure a lasting convenience of that kind.
Really?
What happened?
Who was the man?
Did Mr Darcy give you his reasons for this interference?
What kind of objections? Her lack of fortune?
So he separated them?
I wish Mr Darcy and all his friends well in finding partners suitable to their very high standards. Good morning, Col.
Sir, I appreciate the struggle you have been through, and I am very sorry to have caused you pain. Believe me, it was unconsciously done.
Yes, sir.
No?

Do you deny it, Mr Darcy? That you separated a young couple who loved each other, exposing your friend to the censure of the world for caprice, and my sister to its derision for disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest kind?
How could you do it?
That's because she's shy!
Because you suggested it!
My sister hardly shows her true feelings to me!
I suppose you suspect that his fortune had some bearing on the matter?
What was?
Did my sister give that impression?
Our want of connection? Mr Bingley didn't vex himself about that!
How, sir?

You have ruined his chances, and yet treat him with sarcasm?
My pride?
And those are the words of a gentleman?
I was caught somewhat off-guard.
No! Charlotte, I shall be quite all right. Please, give Lady de Bourgh my apologies. You must not keep her waiting.
I do not know. I hardly know myself.
How is Jane?
Nothing. Everything as you might imagine.

If you, dear father, will not take the trouble to check her, she will be fixed forever as the silliest and most determined flirt who ever made her family ridiculous. And Kitty will follow, as she always does.
Peace! Is that all you care about?
Father, its dangerous! -
No wonder our family is treated with contempt.
I don't wish to be stuck with such a foolish family any longer, with your constant talk of men and marriages.
Believe me, men are either eaten up with arrogance or stupidity. And if they're amiable they're so easily led that they have no minds of their own whatsoever.
No, they bring nothing but heartache.
I saw Mr Darcy when I was in Rosings.
No. He did not.
I would rather stay here.

No.
I'm visiting Derbyshire with my uncle and aunt.
Very pleasant. Tomorrow we go to Matlock.

Goodbye, Mr Darcy.
To dine with him?
His sister?

Your brother is well, I trust?
Yes, very.
It is so beautiful up here. I will be sorry to leave.
You have been a most gracious host. I'm sure my aunt and uncle will talk of nothing else for days.
It does you credit, sir.
It is the most dreadful news. Lydia has run away - with Mr Wickham. They are gone together from Brighton to Lord knows where. She has no money, no connections, I fear she is lost forever.
No, this is my fault. I might have prevented all of it by merely being open with my sisters rather than too proud with my knowledge.
Father has gone to London. But I know very well that nothing can be done. We have not the smallest hope.
Sir, it think it is too late.
He hasn't found him yet, Mama.

Oh father, I'm so sorry.
